Posts.Content: Yes crop tops are great. I wear them with pjs to make me look less uneven (I have one more perky with a slice off the bottom and one rather droopy and somewhat larger). I also have Royce cotton and M&S cotton rich bras non wired. My old lady bras I call them. They’re not seam free and not the most attractive but are very comfortable and miss my underarm scar. Liz x
Posts.Title: Best bra after sentinal lymph node biopsy

Posts.Content: I just wanted to say a very big thank you to Leolady56 and everyone else for all the helpful tips for getting through Rads. I know I’ve had a really easy ride with the Big C but really appreciate all of your experience. The tip about the silk hankie under your bra is AMAZING! I’m on 11/20 with last 5 being boosts and have Bolus on my boob job scar. I’ve been a bit paranoid about my bra strap rubbing that area so asked the radiographer who said go bra less (not something I do being of generous boobage). After a couple of days in a crop top and with plenty of dog walking, the scar is still great but managed to give myself a bit of joggers nipple with all the unsupported jiggling.Two days with the silk scarf and plenty of cream and I’m almost back to ‘new’ normal. You guys are life (and nipple!) savers. Liz x
Posts.Title: October 2018 Radiotherapy Club

Posts.Content: Raygriff12 Just bumping this thread to the top for you. Good luck with everything. Liz x
Posts.Title: October 2018 Radiotherapy Club

Posts.Content: Hi Kate Well done for getting through the op. That’s great news about the nodes. I’ve not actually seen my surgeon yet, just someone from his team, so I know nothing other than they removed a tumour and 2 nodes for biopsy (1 big, 1 little).  Concentrate on healing and try not to worry too much for the next 2 weeks (nigh on impossible I know).  Whatever will be will be and we will deal with it.  Big hugs Liz
Posts.Title: New Here, diagnosed yesterday

Posts.Content: Oh OCRKate I’m sorry to hear that - not the news you wanted but at least it’s been found and can be dealt with. Cry all you need to but just know that now you will now have a plan to deal with the nasty little buggers. Sending you lots of hugs. Liz xxx
Posts.Title: New Here, diagnosed yesterday

Posts.Content: Well done! A shower and hair wash really make you feel better don’t they.  Have fun going back to work. The anaesthetic really took it out of me so only started feeling like myself mid last week. I work in an infant school so pretty hands on so I’m not due back till this Thursday but have popped in a couple of times.  Keep us posted on how you do and results etc. xx
Posts.Title: New Here, diagnosed yesterday

Posts.Content: Hi hope your op today went well and Trevor is long gone! I am new to here and was diagnosed with 18mm grade 1 idc a few weeks ago. No sign of lymph node involvement but they wanted to remove a couple to check. I had a wle with snb last week and now I’m stressing about them having to go back in and remove more. Scary isn’t it.  Thinking about everyone in a similar situation but it’s heartening to read how others have dealt with it before us. Best wishes Liz x
Posts.Title: New Here, diagnosed yesterday

Posts.Content: Hi I’m loving the recycling ideas.  I’m wondering if any refugee charities might take any unused medication and transport it to areas where it is hard to get hold of. I’ll look into it.  I’ll also ask my pharmacist friend. L x
Posts.Title: Squeezing some good out of this nasty disease

Posts.Content: Hi - I’ve just had my first rads today and I need to use the DIBH technique. It was actually really easy. I had a little screen showing my breathing and the range when I needed to hold it in. Good luck with it all - they’ll help you all the way through it. Liz x
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy - DIBH technique

Posts.Content: Hi kathleen37 Yes I was a bit surprised too when I asked in my final week of radiotherapy how they knew where to aim the boost. They seemed surprised that I hadn’t been told that clips had been put in when they removed the tumour to mark where it had been. Mine are in there for good now apparently but shouldn’t set off any security alarms! Definitely a postcode lottery for information. Liz x
Posts.Title: November 2018 Radiotherapy Thread

Posts.Content: Sending you much love and hugs. It’s a bad time but try not to google. Just stick to this or breast cancer care sites. Everyone on here is very supportive and will be there holding your hand (virtually) throughout. Has your consultant given you a plan of treatment yet? Liz xx
Posts.Title: Morning after diagnosis.....

Posts.Content: Hi Kaz18 I’ll be thinking of you tmrw. It’s all the unknowns that’s so hard. Even if it’s not the best news they will have a plan for you and do their best to rid you of the critters. You are in the best hands. Hugs Liz x
Posts.Title: MRI results & surgery / treatment plan tomorrow

Posts.Content: Hi all I’d wondered about the R1 and R2 creams but got waylaid with getting daughter off to uni then rads started. I’m going to ask the radiographers about them and other stuff at my appt tmrw morning. Liz x
Posts.Title: Everything and the Big C

Posts.Content: Hi Misty Blue I’m so very sorry that you have been let down by the very people who should have been looking out for you but I’m pleased that you’ve come here and seem to be sorting yourself out. The NHS is such an unwieldy beast, isn’t it. Everyone here is so friendly, supportive and helpful and I hope you’ll get comfort from being here. Your book sounds really interesting. I’m fascinated with that era (my parents had me relatively late and I lost one uncle in WW2 so I feel quite connected to it in a way). Sending you lots of hugs. Liz x
Posts.Title: Abandoned, Isolated, Alone
